support_summary: ATF6α is crucial for maintaining lipid homeostasis under ER stress. In ATF6α knockout mice, pharmacological ER stress leads to the destabilization of Apolipoprotein B-100 (ApoB-100), which suppresses the formation and secretion of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) and results in hepatic steatosis.

functions.cellular_process: ATF6 activation upregulates genes involved in the formation of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL), including chaperones and folding enzymes necessary for the proper processing and stabilization of Apolipoprotein B-100 (ApoB-100).
functions.effect_description: ATF6 activation promotes the stability and proper folding of ApoB-100, the core structural protein of VLDL, thereby enhancing VLDL particle assembly and secretion from hepatocytes.
biological_consequence: ER Stress → Activation of ATF6α via UPR Pathway → Nuclear Translocation of Active ATF6α → Upregulation of Chaperone and Folding Enzyme Genes → Enhanced Folding and Stabilization of ApoB-100 → Increased VLDL Assembly and Secretion → Prevention of Hepatic Steatosis.
specific_effects: Absence of ATF6α leads to destabilization of Apolipoprotein B-100 under ER stress.
ATF6α knockout mice exhibit suppressed very-low-density lipoprotein formation when challenged with an ER stressor.
ATF6 links the ER stress response to lipid metabolism and the prevention of steatosis.

evidence.paper_title: Regulation of lipid metabolism by the unfolded protein response
evidence.authors: Moncan M, Pou-Promène R, Valet P, Samalens C, Le-Gonidec S

evidence.relevant_quote: Three ER membrane proteins, namely inositol-requiring enzyme 1 (IRE1), protein kinase RNA-like ER kinase (PERK) and activating transcription factor 6 (ATF6), sense the accumulation of unfolded/misfolded proteins and are activated, initiating an integrated transcriptional programme.

summary: ATF6 activates Apolipoprotein B-100 to modulate vldl assembly and secretion, ultimately affecting prevention of hepatic steatosis.
